chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;'s client authentication and authorization filters. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy these &PRODNAME; filters, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.
This handbook is focused on two closely-related &PRODNAME; filters. Other &PRODNAME; filters are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: What Authentication and Authorization Filters Are in Repose
chapter.para: Authentication and authorization are related but independent ideas:

listitem.para: Authentication is the process of confirming that you are who you say you are. For example, you might be asked to authenticate your identity by providing credentials such as a userid, password, account number, or token. Authentication is often abbreviated as Auth-N.

Authorization is the process of confirming that you have permission to do what you are asking to do. For example, your authenticated identity might be checked against a list of the services to which you have subscribed. Authorization is often abbreviated as Auth-Z.

chapter.title: What the Authentication Filter Can Do in Repose
chapter.para: Repose includes a filter designed to support client authentication and another filter designed to support authorization. Both authentication and authorization processes are commonly used by software that requires users to register their identities and subscribe to specific services.

Repose's client authentication component enables the origin service to communicate with the authentication service implemented in its environment. Repose calls the authentication service and returns the results of authentication requests to the origin service.

The Repose client authentication component acts as an HTTP reverse proxy. It passes incoming HTTP requests to an external authentication service. If the authentication service validates the request, Repose adds header information to the HTTP request and forwards it to the origin service. If the authentication service rejects the request, Repose returns the HTTP response to the client.

important.para: If you wish to use &PRODNAME; for authorization, you must first use it for authentication.

chapter.title: How Authentication Is Configured in &PRODNAME;
chapter.para: You can configure your service to use Repose's authentication filter to validate the identities of your users.

Client authentication is divided into modules which represent different authentication schemes. Depending on the Repose components being deployed, the authentication configuration may change. In the following example, we are configuring the client-auth Repose filter to interact with the Rackspace Cloud Authentication Service.

The Repose client authentication filter is implemented as an "Auth Filter" as described in the "Authentication in OpenStack" blueprint at http://wiki.openstack.org/openstack-authn. As such, Repose's authentication lifecycle is directly derived from the blueprint, which defines a standard for authentication. Compliance with this standard enables services to support multiple authentication protocols in a pluggable manner.

section.title: Get Authentication Token from Request Header
section.para: If the incoming HTTP request X-Auth-Token header does not have an auth token then Repose performs the same steps as when the Tenant ID is missing. Thus, both the Tenant ID and the X-Auth-Token must be present in order for Repose to attempt to validate user credentials.

If the requesting client is able to authenticate and is passed down the request chain, the Authentication Filter will set X-PP-User and X-PP-Groups according to the schema of the Authentication service. The Authentication Filter will also set a quality with a value of '1' for these headers.

section.title: Validate Tenant ID/Token with Auth Service
section.para: If the Repose authentication component successfully obtains the Tenant ID and the token from the request, then Repose will send a request to the external Auth Service to validate the Token.

para.emphasis: If the token is valid, then Repose does the following:

listitem.para: Perform another request against the external Auth Service to retrieve the user's groups using the user id from the validated token. If attribute "request-groups="false"" then another request against external Auth Service to to retrieve the user's groups is not made.

Add the groups to the X-PP-Groups request header to be consumed by the Repose Rate Limiting component. If attribute "request-groups="false"" then X-PP-Groups request header will not be set for Repose Rate Limiting component if that is expected, Rate Limiting will be working with the group that is set default to true in Rate Limiting configuration. By Default request-groups attribute is true.
Add the user ID to the X-PP-User request header to be consumed by the Repose Rate Limiting component.
Set the X-User-Name header with the username returned in the validated Token object. Set the X-User-Id header with the user id returned in the validated Token object.
Set the X-Tenant-Name header with the Tenant Id passed in on the URL.
Set the X-Tenant-Id header with the Tenant Id passed in on the URL.
Set the X-Roles header with the roles returned in the validated Token object.
Set the X-Authorization header to "Proxy userId".
If delegatable="true" then set X-Identity-Status to "Confirmed".
Pass the updated request to the origin service.

section.para:
If the token is not valid, then Repose does the following:
Set the X-Authorization header to "Proxy userId".
If delegatable="true" then set X-Identity-Status to "Indeterminate".
If delegatable="true" then pass the updated request to the origin service.

section.title: Authentication Features
section.para: The Repose authentication filter offers a few features designed to simplify the authentication process.

section.title: White List
section.para: REPOSE authentication may be configured to allow the processing of requests that do not require authentication. For example, a service might want all calls authenticated with the exception of the call for wadl retrieval. In this situation, the REPOSE white list may be configured as shown in the sample authentication configuration file:
Sample OpenStack Identity Service Authentication Configuration

The white-list contains a list of regular expressions REPOSE will attempt to match against the full request URI. If the URI matches a regular expression on the white list, then the request is passed to the origin service. Otherwise, authentication is performed against the request.

section.title: Caching
section.para: REPOSE authentication provides caching for user tokens, roles, and groups. The amount of time tokens and roles are cached is determined by the Time To Live (TTL) returned from the authentication service (e.g. Rackspace Identity) during token validation. The TTL for caching of auth tokens and roles can be specified in the client auth configuration file. If token-cache-timeout is specified in the config file, then this value is used when caching tokens and roles, unless the token TTL is less than the token-cache-timeout. If the tokens TTL is less than the configured TTL, then the token's TTL is used. This will prevent REPOSE from caching stale tokens. If the tokens TTL exceeds the max allowed TTL, then the max allowed TTL is used.

The amount of time the user groups are cached is determined by a REPOSE configuration attribute: group-cache-timeout. This attribute is optional and defaults to 600000 milliseconds (10 minutes) if not specified. The group-cache-timeout attribute may be set in the OpenStack or Rackspace authentication schemas as shown in the example client-auth-n.cfg.xml.

section.title: OpenStack Identity Service Authentication
section.para: The &PRODNAME; client authentication filter supports the OpenStack Identity Service authentication scheme. Using this authentication scheme, the &PRODNAME; client authentication filter may be configured to interact with Keystone or Rackspace Cloud Auth 2.0 (both of which implement the OpenStack Identity Service contract) when validating user credentials.

figure.title: Request/Response Lifecycle for Authentication by the OpenStack Identity Service

section.para:
At a high level, the request/response lifecycle is:
The client authentication filter receives a request from the client.
The incoming HTTP request must have a URI and a token in the X-Auth-Token request header. The URI may contain the tenant ID.
The authentication filter parses the URI in the request, extracting the tenant ID and token.
&PRODNAME;'s authentication filter parses the URI using a configurable regular expression (id-reg in the client-auth-n-cfg.xml file) to extract the tenant ID. If the tenant ID is missing, &PRODNAME; does not call the external authentication filter; instead, &PRODNAME; sets the X-Authorization header with no user entry (for example, X-Authorization: Proxy). If the origin service is configured to run in delegated mode, then the X-Identity-Status HTTP header is set to a value of Indeterminate. The request is then passed along to the origin service with the X-Authorization and X-Identity-Status request headers set as described above.
The &PRODNAME; client authentication filter identifies whether the origin service is in delegated mode based on the Boolean value of the delegable attribute in the client-auth-n-cfg.xml file.
If the tenant ID is missing and the origin service is not running in delegated mode (delegable="false" in the client-auth-n-cfg.xml file), then the &PRODNAME; client authentication filter does not forward the request to the origin service. Instead, the &PRODNAME; client authentication filter returns a 401 to the client.
The incoming HTTP request's X-Auth-Token header does not have an authentication token, then &PRODNAME; performs the same steps as when the tenant ID is missing. Both the tenant ID and the X-Auth-Token must be present before &PRODNAME; attempts to validate user credentials.
&PRODNAME; sends a token validation request to an external authentication service.
If the &PRODNAME; authentication filter successfully obtains the tenant ID and the token from the request, then &PRODNAME; sends a request to the external authentication service.

Using the user ID from the validated token, perform another request against the external authentication service to retrieve the user's groups.
Add the groups to the X-PP-Groups request header, to be consumed by the &PRODNAME; rate limiting filter.
Add the user ID to the X-PP-User request header, to be consumed by the &PRODNAME; rate limiting filter.
Set the X-User-Name header with the username returned in the validated token object.
Set the X-User-Id header with the user ID returned in the validated token object.
Set the X-Tenant-Id header with the tenant ID extracted from the URL.
Set the X-Roles header with the roles returned in the validated token object.
Set the X-Authorization header to Proxy userid.
If delegegateable=true, then set X-Identity-Statusto Indeterminate.

The &PRODNAME; authentication filter handles the response from the origin service as described in the "Authentication in OpenStack" blueprint at http://wiki.openstack.org/openstack-authn.
The &PRODNAME; authentication filter returns the request to the &PRODNAME; filter chain for further processing.
When all processing is complete, either the request is passed on to the origin service or a response is sent to the client.

section.title: Rackspace Cloud Auth 1.1 Authentication
section.para: The &PRODNAME; authentication filter supports the Rackspace Cloud Auth 1.1 authentication scheme.

figure.title: Request/Response Lifecycle for Authentication by Rackspace Auth 1.1

section.para:
At a high level, the request/response lifecycle is:
The client authentication filter receives a request from the client.
The incoming HTTP request must have a URI and a token in the X-Auth-Token request header. The URI may contain the tenant ID.
The authentication filter parses the URI in the request, extracting the tenant ID and token.
&PRODNAME; sends a token validation request to an external authentication service.
The &PRODNAME; authentication filter caches the user's token until the token's expiration time.
The &PRODNAME; authentication filter returns the request to the &PRODNAME; filter chain for further processing.
When all processing is complete, either the request is passed on to the origin service or a response is sent to the client.

chapter.title: Client Authorization in &PRODNAME;
chapter.para:
The client authorization service filter enables the service implementer to validate that a client's request is allowed.
If the client's request is allowed, then the request is passed through without any changes.
If the client's request is not allowed, then the request is denied with an HTTP 403 (forbidden) response.
A request is considered authorized if any of the endpoints in the client's endpoint list start with the service endpoint associated with the requested filter. For example, if an authenticated client requests the compute service, and that client's endpoint list (also known as a service catalog) includes an endpoint for the compute service, then the client is authorized to use the compute service and the client's request is forwarded to the compute service for further processing.
The &PRODNAME; authorization filter's decision flow is summarized in the drawing below:

figure.title: Decision Flow in the &PRODNAME; Client Authorization Filter

chapter.para: As shown above, the authorization filter must be configured to represent a valid endpoint. The client receives a token as a result of successful authentication; the identity server uses the client's token to retrieve the client's endpoint list. The authorization filter then compares the configured endpoint against the authenticated client's endpoint list.

important.para: The authorization filter assumes that any requests passed to it have already been authenticated.

section.para: The &PRODNAME; authorization filter must be able to communicate with an OpenStack identity server to obtain a client's endpoint list. You make this possible by defining rackspace-authorization in your &PRODNAME; configuration. This configuration element informs the authorization filter how to contact the OpenStack identity server, which credentials to use when contacting the OpenStack identity server, and how long to cache responses from the OpenStack identity server.

tr.td: The username to send to theOpenStack identity server when authenticating the filter for admin calls
The password to send to theOpenStack identity server when authenticating the filter for admin calls
The full, valid URL of the OpenStack identity server
Duration in seconds for how long the filter will cache (time to live (TTL)) a valid endpoint-list from the OpenStack identity server

section.para:
The authorization filter must be able to identify which service it represents when inspecting a client's endpoint list. The service-endpoint configuration element informs the authorization filter of the service endpoint's public URL. If the service endpoint's public URL matches one of the endpoints in the client's endpoint list, the client is authorized to use that service. Service Endpoint Configuration Element Attributes
Configuration Attribute Type Required? Description
href anyURI YES A valid URL that can be used to match against the publicURL values in the client's endpoint list.
In a client's endpoint list (also known as service catalog), each endpoint must specify its publicURL and type if the client is to be authorized by using the &PRODNAME; authorization service and the OpenStack identity service. This is a requirement of the OpenStack identity service contract. If any required endpoint elements are null for any endpoint in the client's endpoint list, &PRODNAME; issues a warning:
If publicURL is null, the warning is Endpoint Public URL is null. This is a violation of the OpenStack Identity Service contract.
If type is null, the warning is Endpoint Type is null. This is a violation of the OpenStack Identity Service contract.
After issuing the appropriate warning, &PRODNAME; ignores the invalidly-specified endpoint and continues processing the other endpoints in the list.
